text: <|user|> What is considered a high blood pressure reading? <|eos|> <|ai|> Blood pressure readings recorded with 2 numbers. The systolic pressure (higher number) is considered high when it is above 140, while the diastolic pressure (lower number) is high when it is above 90. However, readings between 120/80mmHg and 140/90mmHg could mean you're at risk of developing high blood pressure if you do not take steps to keep your blood pressure under control. The ideal blood pressure is usually between 90/60mmHg and 120/80mmHg. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What are the risks of having high blood pressure? <|eos|> <|ai|> If your blood pressure is too high, it puts extra strain on your blood vessels, heart and other organs, such as the brain, kidneys, and eyes. Persistent high blood pressure can increase your risk of a number of serious and potentially life-threatening health conditions, such as heart disease, heart attacks, strokes, heart failure, peripheral arterial disease, aortic aneurysms, kidney disease, and vascular dementia. However, reducing high blood pressure even a small amount can help lower your risk of these health conditions. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What lifestyle changes can help prevent and lower high blood pressure? <|eos|> <|ai|> These lifestyle changes can help prevent and lower high blood pressure: reduce the amount of salt you eat and have a generally healthy diet, cut back on alcohol, lose weight if you're overweight, exercise regularly, cut down on caffeine, and stop smoking. However, the effectiveness of these changes may vary for each person and it's important to talk to your doctor about your options. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What kind of medicines can help control high blood pressure? <|eos|> <|ai|> If you're diagnosed with high blood pressure, your doctor may recommend taking one or more medicines to keep it under control. These medicines include ACE inhibitors, angiotensin-2 receptor blockers (ARBs), calcium channel blockers, diuretics, beta blockers, alpha blockers, and other diuretics. The medicine recommended for you will depend on things like how high your blood pressure is, your age, and your ethnicity. However, it's important to talk to your doctor before taking any medicine and to follow their instructions carefully. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What are some things that can increase the risk of getting high blood pressure? <|eos|> <|ai|> There are several things that can increase the risk of getting high blood pressure, including being overweight, eating too much salt and not enough fruits and vegetables, not doing enough exercise, drinking too much alcohol or coffee, smoking, not getting enough sleep or having disturbed sleep, being over 65 years old, having a relative with high blood pressure, being of black African or black Caribbean descent, and living in a deprived area. However, making healthy lifestyle changes can sometimes help reduce your chances of getting high blood pressure and help lower your blood pressure if it's already high. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What is bronchiolitis and who is most susceptible to it? <|eos|> <|ai|> Bronchiolitis is a chest infection that usually affects infants and children under two years of age. It is caused by a viral infection, commonly the Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV). Children who were born prematurely, have a heart or lung condition, or weakened immune system, are at higher risk of getting severely ill with bronchiolitis. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What are the signs of bronchiolitis in children and when should I seek medical attention? <|eos|> <|ai|> The early signs of bronchiolitis are similar to that of a cold including sneezing, a runny or blocked nose, a cough, and a slightly high temperature of 38C. Other symptoms include breathing more quickly, difficulty feeding or eating, noisy breathing (wheezing), and irritability. The cough usually gets better within 3 weeks. Seek immediate medical attention by calling 999 or going to the A&E if your child is having difficulty breathing, there are pauses when your child breathes, your child's skin, tongue or lips are blue, or your child is floppy and will not wake up or stay awake. For urgent help, ask for an urgent GP appointment or call 111 if your child has had a cold and it is getting worse, your child is not eating or drinking as normal, your child has been dry for 12 hours or more or shows other signs of dehydration, or your baby has a fever of 38C or higher if under 3 months old or a fever of 39C or higher if older than 3 months. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What treatments are available for bronchiolitis? <|eos|> <|ai|> There is no specific cure for bronchiolitis, but it can be treated at home. You can give your child children's paracetamol to babies and children over two months or ibuprofen to babies and children over three months. If your child's nose is blocked, try using saline drops and keep them upright as much as possible when they are awake. Encourage your child to drink lots of fluids. Do not give aspirin to children under the age of 16. Hospital treatment may be necessary for children who are severely affected. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> How can bronchiolitis be prevented? <|eos|> <|ai|> To prevent the incidence of bronchiolitis in children, there are several measures parents can take. Regular hand washing is highly recommended, and cleaning surfaces frequently, keeping newborn babies away from other kids who have a cold or flu are other preventative measures. Use disposable tissues and throw them away right after use and avoid smoking around your child because second-hand smoke puts children at higher risk of getting bronchiolitis. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What is the difference between bronchiolitis and bronchitis? <|eos|> <|ai|> Bronchiolitis usually affects babies and children under 2 and does not usually progress beyond their tenth day of illness. It causes symptoms such as runny or blocked nose, cough, and difficulty breathing. Bronchitis, on the other hand, affects people of all ages and causes cough with lots of mucus. Symptoms of bronchitis include cough, fatigue, slight fever, and chest discomfort. Unlike bronchiolitis, bronchitis can last from several days to weeks. <|eos|> <|eod|>

Do you have a high temperature or any chest pain? <|eos|> <|user|> Yes, I do have a high temperature and sometimes feel chest pain when I cough. <|eos|> <|ai|> It's important to take painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen to help with pain and bring down a high temperature. <|user|> Hi, I have been experiencing joint pain lately. Can steroids help me with the pain? <|eos|> <|ai|> Hi! Steroids can be used to treat joint pain caused by conditions like arthritis or frozen shoulder. However, it's important to only take them as prescribed by your doctor, as steroids can have side effects. <|eos|> <|user|> What are the different types of steroids available? <|eos|> <|ai|> Steroids come in many different forms. The main types are tablets, syrups, liquids, inhalers, nasal sprays, injections, creams, lotions, and gels. Most steroids are only available on prescription, but a few (such as some creams or nasal sprays) can be bought from pharmacies and shops. <|eos|> <|user|> Are there any side effects of taking steroids? <|eos|> <|ai|> Steroids do not tend to cause significant side effects if they're taken for a short time or at a low dose. But sometimes they can cause unpleasant side effects, such as an increased appetite, mood changes, and difficulty sleeping. This is most common with steroid tablets. The side effects will usually pass once you finish the treatment, but do not stop taking your medicine without speaking to your doctor. <|eos|> <|user|> Can steroids be used to treat eczema? <|eos|> <|ai|> Yes, steroids can be used to treat eczema. Creams, lotions, and gels containing steroids can be applied directly onto the skin to help reduce redness and itching caused by eczema or other skin conditions. <|eos|> <|user|> I have recently been diagnosed with lupus. Can steroids help me with this condition? <|eos|> <|ai|> Yes, steroids can be used to treat autoimmune conditions like lupus. Steroids reduce the activity of the immune system, which is the body's natural defense against illness and infection. This can help treat autoimmune conditions, such as rheumatoid arthritis or lupus, which are caused by the immune system mistakenly attacking the body. However, you should always follow the treatment plan prescribed by your doctor, as steroids can have side effects if not taken correctly. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What are the symptoms of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease? <|eos|> <|ai|> The symptoms of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease include loss of intellect and memory, changes in personality, loss of balance and co-ordination, slurred speech, vision problems and blindness, abnormal jerking movements, and progressive loss of brain function and mobility. Most people with CJD will die within a year of the symptoms starting, usually from infection. This is because the immobility caused by CJD can make people with the condition vulnerable to infection. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What is the cause of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease? <|eos|> <|ai|> Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease appears to be caused by an abnormal infectious protein called a prion. These prions accumulate at high levels in the brain and cause irreversible damage to nerve cells. While the abnormal prions are technically infectious, they're very different from viruses and bacteria. For example, prions aren't destroyed by the extremes of heat and radiation used to kill bacteria and viruses, and antibiotics or antiviral medicines have no effect on them. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What are the types of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease? <|eos|> <|ai|> There are 4 main types of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Sporadic CJD, which is the most common type, occurs when the normal brain protein changes abnormally ("misfolds") and turns into a prion. Variant CJD is likely to be caused by consuming meat from a cow that had bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE, or "mad cow" disease), a similar prion disease to CJD. Familial CJD is a very rare genetic condition. Iatrogenic CJD is where the infection is accidentally spread from someone with CJD through medical or surgical treatment. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> How is Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease treated? <|eos|> <|ai|> There's currently no cure for Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, so treatment aims to relieve symptoms and make the affected person feel as comfortable as possible. This can include using medicine such as antidepressants to help with anxiety and depression, and painkillers to relieve pain. Some people will need nursing care and assistance with feeding. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What is the Variant CJD compensation scheme? <|eos|> <|ai|> In October 2001, the government announced a compensation scheme for UK victims of variant CJD. The vCJD Trust assesses claims and pays compensation to victims and their families. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What is HIV and how does it affect the body? <|eos|> <|ai|> HIV, or human immunodeficiency virus, is a virus that attacks the immune system by damaging the cells responsible for fighting infections and diseases. When HIV is left untreated, it can progress to AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, which is a life-threatening condition that occurs when the immune system has been severely damaged. HIV weakens the immune system and makes it more difficult for the body to fight common infections and diseases, which can result in severe illnesses and even death. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> How is HIV transmitted from one person to another? <|eos|> <|ai|> HIV is primarily transmitted through the exchange of body fluids, including semen, vaginal fluids, blood, and breast milk. The most common way of getting HIV is through unprotected anal or vaginal sex with an infected person. Sharing needles, syringes, or other injecting equipment with someone who is infected with HIV can also lead to transmission. Finally, HIV can be transmitted from mother to baby during pregnancy, birth, or breastfeeding. It's important to note that HIV cannot be transmitted through sweat, urine, or saliva. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What are some effective ways to prevent or reduce the risk of HIV infection? <|eos|> <|ai|> There are several effective ways to prevent or reduce the risk of HIV infection, including using a condom during sex, practicing post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) following potential exposure to the virus, taking pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), and using treatment for HIV to reduce the viral load to undetectable levels. If you use drugs, never share needles or other injecting equipment, including syringes, spoons, and swabs. It's important to speak with your local sexual health clinic or a GP for further advice about the best way to reduce your risk. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What are some common symptoms of HIV infection? <|eos|> <|ai|> Most people experience a short flu-like illness 2 to 6 weeks after HIV infection, which lasts for a week or 2. After these symptoms disappear, HIV may not cause any symptoms for many years, but the virus continues to damage the immune system. This means many people with HIV do not know they're infected. Anyone who thinks they could have HIV should get tested. Some people are advised to have regular tests as they're at particularly high risk. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What are some of the ways to diagnose HIV? <|eos|> <|ai|> The only way to find out if you have HIV is to have an HIV test. This involves testing a sample of your blood or saliva for signs of the infection. You can get tested in a number of places, including at a GP surgery, sexual health clinics, and clinics run by charities. It's recommended to seek medical advice as soon as possible if you think you might have been exposed to HIV. Clinics may offer a finger prick blood test, which can give you a result in minutes, but it may take up to a few days to get the results of a more detailed HIV test. Home testing or home sampling kits are also available to buy online or from pharmacies. If your first test suggests you have HIV, a further blood test will need to be carried out to confirm the result. If this is positive, you'll be referred to a specialist HIV clinic for some more tests and a discussion about your treatment options. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> Hi, I'm a bit worried about some symptoms I've been experiencing. Can you tell me more about heart attacks? <|eos|> <|ai|> Of course, I can help you with that. What specifically would you like to know? <|eos|> <|user|> What are the symptoms of a heart attack? <|eos|> <|ai|> Symptoms of a heart attack can include chest pain, pain in other parts of the body, feeling lightheaded or dizzy, sweating, shortness of breath, feeling sick or being sick, an overwhelming feeling of anxiety, coughing or wheezing. The chest pain is often severe, but some people may only experience minor pain, similar to indigestion. <|eos|> <|user|> What should I do if I think I'm having a heart attack? <|eos|> <|ai|> If you suspect a heart attack, it's important to call 999 and ask for an ambulance immediately. The faster you act, the better your chances of survival. <|eos|> <|user|> How is a heart attack treated? <|eos|> <|ai|> In hospital, treatment for a heart attack depends on how serious it is. The two main treatments are using medicines to dissolve blood clots and surgery to help restore blood to the heart. <|eos|> <|user|> What causes a heart attack? <|eos|> <|ai|> Coronary heart disease (CHD) is the leading cause of heart attacks. CHD is a condition in which the major blood vessels that supply the heart get clogged with deposits of cholesterol, known as plaques. Before a heart attack, one of the plaques bursts (ruptures), causing a blood clot to develop at the site of the rupture. <|eos|> <|user|> Can a heart attack be prevented? <|eos|> <|ai|> There are 5 main steps you can take to reduce your risk of having a heart attack: smokers should quit smoking, lose weight if you're overweight or obese, do regular exercise, eat a healthy diet and moderate your alcohol consumption. These lifestyle changes can help reduce your risk of heart disease and heart attacks. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What are the main symptoms of laryngitis? <|eos|> <|ai|> The main symptoms of laryngitis are a hoarse (croaky) voice, sometimes losing your voice, an irritating cough that does not go away, always needing to clear your throat, and a sore throat. Children can also have a temperature of 38C or above, be off their food or drink, or have difficulty breathing (but this is rare). Laryngitis is often linked to other illnesses, such as colds and flu, so you may also have other symptoms. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> Can laryngitis be treated at home? <|eos|> <|ai|> Yes, laryngitis can be treated at home. Laryngitis usually goes away on its own after 1 to 2 weeks and you do not need to see a GP. To treat laryngitis at home, try to speak as little as possible, drink plenty of fluids, keep the air moist by putting out bowls of water, gargle with warm salty water (not suitable for younger children), and avoid talking loudly or whispering, smoking, spending time in smoky or dusty places, and drinking too much caffeine or alcohol as they cause dehydration. Speak to a pharmacist about your sore throat for advice and treatments, including paracetamol or ibuprofen, cough syrup to help with your cough, solutions to gargle, or lozenges for the pain. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What should I do if my laryngitis symptoms do not improve after 2 weeks? <|eos|> <|ai|> If your laryngitis symptoms do not improve after 2 weeks, you should see a GP. The GP will try to work out what has caused your laryngitis and may look inside your throat using a small mirror, wipe a cotton bud around the back of your throat for testing, arrange a blood test, or refer you to an ear, nose and throat (ENT) specialist (if you keep getting laryngitis). If your laryngitis is caused by an infection, the GP might prescribe antibiotics. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What causes laryngitis besides cold or flu infection? <|eos|> <|ai|> Laryngitis can be caused by various factors besides cold or flu infection. Other things that cause laryngitis include allergies to things like dust and fumes, acid from your stomach coming up your throat (acid reflux), coughing over a long time, and clearing your throat all the time. However, laryngitis is often linked to other illnesses, such as colds and flu, so you may also have other symptoms. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What should I do if I or my child is having difficulty breathing due to laryngitis? <|eos|> <|ai|> If you or your child is having difficulty breathing due to laryngitis, you should call 999 or go to A&E immediately. Difficulty breathing is a serious symptom that requires urgent medical attention. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What are the symptoms of multiple sclerosis? <|eos|> <|ai|> The symptoms of multiple sclerosis vary widely from person to person and can affect any part of the body. The main symptoms include fatigue, difficulty walking, vision problems, such as blurred vision, problems controlling the bladder, numbness or tingling in different parts of the body, muscle stiffness and spasms, problems with balance and co-ordination, and problems with thinking, learning and planning. Depending on the type of MS you have, your symptoms may come and go in phases or get steadily worse over time (progress). <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What causes multiple sclerosis? <|eos|> <|ai|> Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune condition. This is when something goes wrong with the immune system and it mistakenly attacks a healthy part of the body – in this case, the brain or spinal cord of the nervous system. In MS, the immune system attacks the layer that surrounds and protects the nerves called the myelin sheath. This damages and scars the sheath, and potentially the underlying nerves, meaning that messages travelling along the nerves become slowed or disrupted. Exactly what causes the immune system to act in this way is unclear, but most experts think a combination of genetic and environmental factors is involved. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What treatments are available for multiple sclerosis? <|eos|> <|ai|> There's currently no cure for multiple sclerosis, but a number of treatments can help control the condition and ease symptoms. The treatment you need will depend on the specific symptoms and difficulties you have. It may include treating relapses with short courses of steroid medicine to speed up recovery, specific treatments for individual MS symptoms, and treatment to reduce the number of relapses using medicines called disease-modifying therapies. Disease-modifying therapies may also help to slow or reduce the overall worsening of disability in people with a type of MS called relapsing remitting MS, and in some people with types called primary and secondary progressive MS, who have relapses. Unfortunately, there's currently no treatment that can slow the progress of primary progressive MS, or secondary progressive MS, where there are no relapses. Many therapies aiming to treat progressive MS are currently being researched. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> What is the outlook for people with multiple sclerosis? <|eos|> <|ai|> Multiple sclerosis can be a challenging condition to live with, but new treatments over the past 20 years have considerably improved the quality of life of people with the condition. MS itself is rarely fatal, but complications may arise from severe MS, such as chest or bladder infections, or swallowing difficulties. The average life expectancy for people with MS is around 5 to 10 years lower than average, and this gap appears to be getting smaller all the time. <|eos|> <|eod|>

<|user|> Where can I find support and advice for multiple sclerosis? <|eos|> <|ai|> If you or someone you know has just been diagnosed with multiple sclerosis, there are 2 main MS charities in the UK: the MS Society and the MS Trust. These organisations offer useful advice, publications, news items about ongoing research, blogs and chatrooms. There's also the shift.ms website, an online community for younger people affected by MS. The social care and support guide explains your options and where you can get support if you need help with day-to-day living because of illness or disability, or if you care for someone regularly because they're ill, elderly or disabled, including family members. <|eos|> <|eod|>
